Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

Trump-Era Tariffs 2.0: Why Dubai Could Be the Biggest Winner!---------------------------------------------------------------------In 2024, the total bilateral trade between the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the United States reached $34.4 billion, marking a significant increase from previous years. This trade volume comprised $26.9 billion in U.S. exports to the UAE and $7.5 billion in imports from the UAE, resulting in a $19.5 billion trade surplus for the U.S.â€”its fourth-largest globally.With the potential return of Trump-era tariffs under a â€œTrump 2.0â€ administration, the UAEâ€”particularly Dubaiâ€”is poised to benefit significantly compared to much of the rest of the world, especially China. As global manufacturers and exporters seek alternative trade routes to bypass high tariffs, Dubai is emerging as a strategic export and re-export hub for Chinese-manufactured goods destined for the U.S. market.This shift positions Dubai not just as a logistics gateway, but as a key trading intermediary between China and the United States, unlocking a new phase of trade growth. In the coming months, this dynamic is expected to fuel unprecedented increases in exports from the UAE to the U.S., as well as reciprocal trade flows.The ripple effects of this transformation will be profoundâ€”particularly for Dubaiâ€™s real estate sector. The demand for commercial infrastructure, including warehouses, logistics parks, and office spaces, is expected to surge. Simultaneously, the residential market is likely to experience heightened demand, driven by business expansion, workforce inflow, and investor interest. Together, these trends are set to reinforce Dubaiâ€™s position as a global trading and real estate hotspot.

Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

Trump-Era Tariffs 2.0: Why Dubai Could Be the Biggest Winner!---------------------------------------------------------------------In 2024, the total bilateral trade between the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the United States reached $34.4 billion, marking a significant increase from previous years. This trade volume comprised $26.9 billion in U.S. exports to the UAE and $7.5 billion in imports from the UAE, resulting in a $19.5 billion trade surplus for the U.S.â€”its fourth-largest globally.With the potential return of Trump-era tariffs under a â€œTrump 2.0â€ administration, the UAEâ€”particularly Dubaiâ€”is poised to benefit significantly compared to much of the rest of the world, especially China. As global manufacturers and exporters seek alternative trade routes to bypass high tariffs, Dubai is emerging as a strategic export and re-export hub for Chinese-manufactured goods destined for the U.S. market.This shift positions Dubai not just as a logistics gateway, but as a key trading intermediary between China and the United States, unlocking a new phase of trade growth. In the coming months, this dynamic is expected to fuel unprecedented increases in exports from the UAE to the U.S., as well as reciprocal trade flows.The ripple effects of this transformation will be profoundâ€”particularly for Dubaiâ€™s real estate sector. The demand for commercial infrastructure, including warehouses, logistics parks, and office spaces, is expected to surge. Simultaneously, the residential market is likely to experience heightened demand, driven by business expansion, workforce inflow, and investor interest. Together, these trends are set to reinforce Dubaiâ€™s position as a global trading and real estate hotspot.

Free zones like Dubai Internet City and Jebel Ali are magnets for digital entrepreneurs. Women-led startups are also reshaping the industry, with innovative businesses across fashion, beauty, and digital services.Challenges for E-Commerce FoundersWhile the opportunities are abundant, challenges persist. Global players like Amazon and Noon dominate, making it tough for smaller players. Additionally, high digital marketing costs, brand visibility issues, and cultural expectations are barriers to success. Businesses must focus on trust, quality, and innovation to stay competitive.Key Takeaways â€¢	Customer Experience is King: Simplified, fast service builds loyalty. â€¢	Niche Wins: Unique positioning helps small brands stand out. â€¢	Consistency & Adaptability: Be ready to pivot based on data and trends.Looking AheadThe future of UAEâ€™s e-commerce will be shaped by technologyâ€”AI, AR, cross-border selling, and fintech integration. Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

Trump-Era Tariffs 2.0: Why Dubai Could Be the Biggest Winner!---------------------------------------------------------------------In 2024, the total bilateral trade between the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the United States reached $34.4 billion, marking a significant increase from previous years. This trade volume comprised $26.9 billion in U.S. exports to the UAE and $7.5 billion in imports from the UAE, resulting in a $19.5 billion trade surplus for the U.S.â€”its fourth-largest globally.With the potential return of Trump-era tariffs under a â€œTrump 2.0â€ administration, the UAEâ€”particularly Dubaiâ€”is poised to benefit significantly compared to much of the rest of the world, especially China. As global manufacturers and exporters seek alternative trade routes to bypass high tariffs, Dubai is emerging as a strategic export and re-export hub for Chinese-manufactured goods destined for the U.S. market.This shift positions Dubai not just as a logistics gateway, but as a key trading intermediary between China and the United States, unlocking a new phase of trade growth. In the coming months, this dynamic is expected to fuel unprecedented increases in exports from the UAE to the U.S., as well as reciprocal trade flows.The ripple effects of this transformation will be profoundâ€”particularly for Dubaiâ€™s real estate sector. The demand for commercial infrastructure, including warehouses, logistics parks, and office spaces, is expected to surge. Simultaneously, the residential market is likely to experience heightened demand, driven by business expansion, workforce inflow, and investor interest. Together, these trends are set to reinforce Dubaiâ€™s position as a global trading and real estate hotspot.

Inside the E-Commerce Boom in the UAE: Opportunities, Challenges, and the Road AheadBy Nigar ValiyevaThe UAEâ€™s e-commerce sector is boomingâ€”and Iâ€™ve lived it from the inside.From founding multiple startups in Dubai to navigating growth and competition, Iâ€™ve seen firsthand what makes this market so powerfulâ€”and where the real challenges lie.In this article, I share key insights, lessons for entrepreneurs, and what the road ahead looks like for digital commerce in the region.Read, comment, and share if you believe in the power of entrepreneurship.hashtag#UAE hashtag#Ecommerce hashtag#Startups hashtag#DigitalBusiness hashtag#WomenInBusiness hashtag#Entrepreneurship hashtag#DubaiThe UAE has quickly become a leading e-commerce hub in the Middle East, thanks to technological advancements, government initiatives, and a tech-savvy population. With platforms like Noon and Amazon becoming household names, the market has seen exponential growth, especially in sectors like fashion, electronics, and food delivery.Opportunities for EntrepreneursThe UAE offers an ideal environment for e-commerce startups, with attractive tax policies and a business-friendly infrastructure. Free zones like Dubai Internet City and Jebel Ali are magnets for digital entrepreneurs. Women-led startups are also reshaping the industry, with innovative businesses across fashion, beauty, and digital services.Challenges for E-Commerce FoundersWhile the opportunities are abundant, challenges persist. Global players like Amazon and Noon dominate, making it tough for smaller players. Additionally, high digital marketing costs, brand visibility issues, and cultural expectations are barriers to success. Businesses must focus on trust, quality, and innovation to stay competitive.Key Takeaways â€¢	Customer Experience is King: Simplified, fast service builds loyalty. â€¢	Niche Wins: Unique positioning helps small brands stand out. â€¢	Consistency & Adaptability: Be ready to pivot based on data and trends.Looking AheadThe future of UAEâ€™s e-commerce will be shaped by technologyâ€”AI, AR, cross-border selling, and fintech integration. Remember The Devil Wears Prada? Dubai is the 2.0 version. Welcome to modern slavery in designer clothes. Since being based here as a freelancer, I've had many people reach out with job offers and opportunities. While this city is known for its glitz and glamour, there are some hard lessons Iâ€™ve learned that I think are important for anyone considering a move here.- While Dubai offers perks like zero income tax and attractive salaries, there are some important realities to consider:-Job security can be shaky â€“ you can be terminated without any explanation during your probation period.-Your immigration status is tied to your employment, and unless you have a golden visa, your residency can be at risk if your job ends suddenly.-The cost of living is high, and even with a half a million salary in your country per month, it might not be enough to cover everything.-Accommodation is super expensive, and itâ€™s rarely paid monthly. In most cases, youâ€™ll be expected to pay rent in 1 or worse case 2 instalments â€“ or best, 4 months upfront â€“ plus all your utility bills on top (electricity, water, air con internet, tv etc.). Your employer will not necessarily pay for hotel costs pending you find an accommodation. -Work culture here can be intense â€“ if your boss works 24/7, so will you, as well as other dodgy work conditions that you cannot fight and under constant pressure of potential termination and deportation.-Forget employment rights. Forget human rights.The city might shine, but not everything that glitters is gold. Be informed, be cautious, and ask the right questions before saying yes.hashtag#Dubai hashtag#FreelancerLife hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#JobOpportunities hashtag#LivingInDubai hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#Immigration hashtag#GoldenVisa hashtag#RealityCheck hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#ExpatLife hashtag#CostOfLiving hashtag#RentalReality hashtag#Utilities hashtag#HardTruths hashtag#ModernSlavery

Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

Trump-Era Tariffs 2.0: Why Dubai Could Be the Biggest Winner!---------------------------------------------------------------------In 2024, the total bilateral trade between the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the United States reached $34.4 billion, marking a significant increase from previous years. This trade volume comprised $26.9 billion in U.S. exports to the UAE and $7.5 billion in imports from the UAE, resulting in a $19.5 billion trade surplus for the U.S.â€”its fourth-largest globally.With the potential return of Trump-era tariffs under a â€œTrump 2.0â€ administration, the UAEâ€”particularly Dubaiâ€”is poised to benefit significantly compared to much of the rest of the world, especially China. As global manufacturers and exporters seek alternative trade routes to bypass high tariffs, Dubai is emerging as a strategic export and re-export hub for Chinese-manufactured goods destined for the U.S. market.This shift positions Dubai not just as a logistics gateway, but as a key trading intermediary between China and the United States, unlocking a new phase of trade growth. In the coming months, this dynamic is expected to fuel unprecedented increases in exports from the UAE to the U.S., as well as reciprocal trade flows.The ripple effects of this transformation will be profoundâ€”particularly for Dubaiâ€™s real estate sector. The demand for commercial infrastructure, including warehouses, logistics parks, and office spaces, is expected to surge. Simultaneously, the residential market is likely to experience heightened demand, driven by business expansion, workforce inflow, and investor interest. Together, these trends are set to reinforce Dubaiâ€™s position as a global trading and real estate hotspot.

Remember The Devil Wears Prada? Dubai is the 2.0 version. Welcome to modern slavery in designer clothes. Since being based here as a freelancer, I've had many people reach out with job offers and opportunities. While this city is known for its glitz and glamour, there are some hard lessons Iâ€™ve learned that I think are important for anyone considering a move here.- While Dubai offers perks like zero income tax and attractive salaries, there are some important realities to consider:-Job security can be shaky â€“ you can be terminated without any explanation during your probation period.-Your immigration status is tied to your employment, and unless you have a golden visa, your residency can be at risk if your job ends suddenly.-The cost of living is high, and even with a half a million salary in your country per month, it might not be enough to cover everything.-Accommodation is super expensive, and itâ€™s rarely paid monthly. In most cases, youâ€™ll be expected to pay rent in 1 or worse case 2 instalments â€“ or best, 4 months upfront â€“ plus all your utility bills on top (electricity, water, air con internet, tv etc.). Your employer will not necessarily pay for hotel costs pending you find an accommodation. -Work culture here can be intense â€“ if your boss works 24/7, so will you, as well as other dodgy work conditions that you cannot fight and under constant pressure of potential termination and deportation.-Forget employment rights. Forget human rights.The city might shine, but not everything that glitters is gold. Be informed, be cautious, and ask the right questions before saying yes.hashtag#Dubai hashtag#FreelancerLife hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#JobOpportunities hashtag#LivingInDubai hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#Immigration hashtag#GoldenVisa hashtag#RealityCheck hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#ExpatLife hashtag#CostOfLiving hashtag#RentalReality hashtag#Utilities hashtag#HardTruths hashtag#ModernSlavery

Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

Trump-Era Tariffs 2.0: Why Dubai Could Be the Biggest Winner!---------------------------------------------------------------------In 2024, the total bilateral trade between the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the United States reached $34.4 billion, marking a significant increase from previous years. This trade volume comprised $26.9 billion in U.S. exports to the UAE and $7.5 billion in imports from the UAE, resulting in a $19.5 billion trade surplus for the U.S.â€”its fourth-largest globally.With the potential return of Trump-era tariffs under a â€œTrump 2.0â€ administration, the UAEâ€”particularly Dubaiâ€”is poised to benefit significantly compared to much of the rest of the world, especially China. As global manufacturers and exporters seek alternative trade routes to bypass high tariffs, Dubai is emerging as a strategic export and re-export hub for Chinese-manufactured goods destined for the U.S. market.This shift positions Dubai not just as a logistics gateway, but as a key trading intermediary between China and the United States, unlocking a new phase of trade growth. In the coming months, this dynamic is expected to fuel unprecedented increases in exports from the UAE to the U.S., as well as reciprocal trade flows.The ripple effects of this transformation will be profoundâ€”particularly for Dubaiâ€™s real estate sector. The demand for commercial infrastructure, including warehouses, logistics parks, and office spaces, is expected to surge. Simultaneously, the residential market is likely to experience heightened demand, driven by business expansion, workforce inflow, and investor interest. Together, these trends are set to reinforce Dubaiâ€™s position as a global trading and real estate hotspot.

Inside the E-Commerce Boom in the UAE: Opportunities, Challenges, and the Road AheadBy Nigar ValiyevaThe UAEâ€™s e-commerce sector is boomingâ€”and Iâ€™ve lived it from the inside.From founding multiple startups in Dubai to navigating growth and competition, Iâ€™ve seen firsthand what makes this market so powerfulâ€”and where the real challenges lie.In this article, I share key insights, lessons for entrepreneurs, and what the road ahead looks like for digital commerce in the region.Read, comment, and share if you believe in the power of entrepreneurship.hashtag#UAE hashtag#Ecommerce hashtag#Startups hashtag#DigitalBusiness hashtag#WomenInBusiness hashtag#Entrepreneurship hashtag#DubaiThe UAE has quickly become a leading e-commerce hub in the Middle East, thanks to technological advancements, government initiatives, and a tech-savvy population. With platforms like Noon and Amazon becoming household names, the market has seen exponential growth, especially in sectors like fashion, electronics, and food delivery.Opportunities for EntrepreneursThe UAE offers an ideal environment for e-commerce startups, with attractive tax policies and a business-friendly infrastructure. Free zones like Dubai Internet City and Jebel Ali are magnets for digital entrepreneurs. Women-led startups are also reshaping the industry, with innovative businesses across fashion, beauty, and digital services.Challenges for E-Commerce FoundersWhile the opportunities are abundant, challenges persist. Global players like Amazon and Noon dominate, making it tough for smaller players. Additionally, high digital marketing costs, brand visibility issues, and cultural expectations are barriers to success. Businesses must focus on trust, quality, and innovation to stay competitive.Key Takeaways â€¢	Customer Experience is King: Simplified, fast service builds loyalty. â€¢	Niche Wins: Unique positioning helps small brands stand out. â€¢	Consistency & Adaptability: Be ready to pivot based on data and trends.Looking AheadThe future of UAEâ€™s e-commerce will be shaped by technologyâ€”AI, AR, cross-border selling, and fintech integration. Remember The Devil Wears Prada? Dubai is the 2.0 version. Welcome to modern slavery in designer clothes. Since being based here as a freelancer, I've had many people reach out with job offers and opportunities. While this city is known for its glitz and glamour, there are some hard lessons Iâ€™ve learned that I think are important for anyone considering a move here.- While Dubai offers perks like zero income tax and attractive salaries, there are some important realities to consider:-Job security can be shaky â€“ you can be terminated without any explanation during your probation period.-Your immigration status is tied to your employment, and unless you have a golden visa, your residency can be at risk if your job ends suddenly.-The cost of living is high, and even with a half a million salary in your country per month, it might not be enough to cover everything.-Accommodation is super expensive, and itâ€™s rarely paid monthly. In most cases, youâ€™ll be expected to pay rent in 1 or worse case 2 instalments â€“ or best, 4 months upfront â€“ plus all your utility bills on top (electricity, water, air con internet, tv etc.). Your employer will not necessarily pay for hotel costs pending you find an accommodation. -Work culture here can be intense â€“ if your boss works 24/7, so will you, as well as other dodgy work conditions that you cannot fight and under constant pressure of potential termination and deportation.-Forget employment rights. Forget human rights.The city might shine, but not everything that glitters is gold. Be informed, be cautious, and ask the right questions before saying yes.hashtag#Dubai hashtag#FreelancerLife hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#JobOpportunities hashtag#LivingInDubai hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#Immigration hashtag#GoldenVisa hashtag#RealityCheck hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#ExpatLife hashtag#CostOfLiving hashtag#RentalReality hashtag#Utilities hashtag#HardTruths hashtag#ModernSlavery

The government is now clearly working within the framework of the Economic Modernization Vision, which is Jordanâ€™s roadmap for achieving sustainable growth by focusing on key parts of the economy. In 2024, macroeconomic indicators showed stability. The economy grew by 2.5 per cent and inflation stayed low at 2.21 per cent. GDP per person reached 3,228 dinars. The budget deficit after aid remained low at 0.7 per cent of GDP. Foreign currency reserves were $22 billion in March 2025, enough to cover 8.5 months of imports. Foreign direct investment reached 1,122 million dinars. Imports totaled 1,623 million dinars, while exports were 703 million dinars.

Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Trump-Era Tariffs 2.0: Why Dubai Could Be the Biggest Winner!---------------------------------------------------------------------In 2024, the total bilateral trade between the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the United States reached $34.4 billion, marking a significant increase from previous years. This trade volume comprised $26.9 billion in U.S. exports to the UAE and $7.5 billion in imports from the UAE, resulting in a $19.5 billion trade surplus for the U.S.â€”its fourth-largest globally.With the potential return of Trump-era tariffs under a â€œTrump 2.0â€ administration, the UAEâ€”particularly Dubaiâ€”is poised to benefit significantly compared to much of the rest of the world, especially China. As global manufacturers and exporters seek alternative trade routes to bypass high tariffs, Dubai is emerging as a strategic export and re-export hub for Chinese-manufactured goods destined for the U.S. market.This shift positions Dubai not just as a logistics gateway, but as a key trading intermediary between China and the United States, unlocking a new phase of trade growth. In the coming months, this dynamic is expected to fuel unprecedented increases in exports from the UAE to the U.S., as well as reciprocal trade flows.The ripple effects of this transformation will be profoundâ€”particularly for Dubaiâ€™s real estate sector. The demand for commercial infrastructure, including warehouses, logistics parks, and office spaces, is expected to surge. Simultaneously, the residential market is likely to experience heightened demand, driven by business expansion, workforce inflow, and investor interest. Together, these trends are set to reinforce Dubaiâ€™s position as a global trading and real estate hotspot.

Inside the E-Commerce Boom in the UAE: Opportunities, Challenges, and the Road AheadBy Nigar ValiyevaThe UAEâ€™s e-commerce sector is boomingâ€”and Iâ€™ve lived it from the inside.From founding multiple startups in Dubai to navigating growth and competition, Iâ€™ve seen firsthand what makes this market so powerfulâ€”and where the real challenges lie.In this article, I share key insights, lessons for entrepreneurs, and what the road ahead looks like for digital commerce in the region.Read, comment, and share if you believe in the power of entrepreneurship.hashtag#UAE hashtag#Ecommerce hashtag#Startups hashtag#DigitalBusiness hashtag#WomenInBusiness hashtag#Entrepreneurship hashtag#DubaiThe UAE has quickly become a leading e-commerce hub in the Middle East, thanks to technological advancements, government initiatives, and a tech-savvy population. With platforms like Noon and Amazon becoming household names, the market has seen exponential growth, especially in sectors like fashion, electronics, and food delivery.Opportunities for EntrepreneursThe UAE offers an ideal environment for e-commerce startups, with attractive tax policies and a business-friendly infrastructure. Free zones like Dubai Internet City and Jebel Ali are magnets for digital entrepreneurs. Women-led startups are also reshaping the industry, with innovative businesses across fashion, beauty, and digital services.Challenges for E-Commerce FoundersWhile the opportunities are abundant, challenges persist. Global players like Amazon and Noon dominate, making it tough for smaller players. Additionally, high digital marketing costs, brand visibility issues, and cultural expectations are barriers to success. Businesses must focus on trust, quality, and innovation to stay competitive.Key Takeaways â€¢	Customer Experience is King: Simplified, fast service builds loyalty. â€¢	Niche Wins: Unique positioning helps small brands stand out. â€¢	Consistency & Adaptability: Be ready to pivot based on data and trends.Looking AheadThe future of UAEâ€™s e-commerce will be shaped by technologyâ€”AI, AR, cross-border selling, and fintech integration. With continued government support and a strong entrepreneurial spirit, the UAE will remain at the forefront of the Middle Eastâ€™s e-commerce revolution.â¸»Nigar ValiyevaE-commerce & Events Entrepreneur | Advocate for Women in BusinessFounder, Dubai Startups: WooWDeal Trading FZE, Shop CartTrading FZE, Bakilili Commercial Broker LLC, Premium Shishas Management LLC

The Art of Anticipatory Luxury at Conrad DubaiAt Conrad Dubai, we believe true luxury lies in the detailsâ€”those thoughtful, unexpected touches that transform a stay into an unforgettable experience. Recently, my team noticed a guestâ€™s sunglasses and laptop in the room and immediately took action. Without being asked, they placed a premium microfiber cloth beside the devices, ensuring a pristine screen at all times. But he didnâ€™t stop thereâ€”He organized the guestâ€™s cables with an elegant cable manager, leaving everything effortlessly tidy. A handwritten note completed the gesture.Later, I had the pleasure of speaking with the guest during his departure. He was genuinely moved by the initiative, saying, "I was amazed that your team thought this wayâ€”no one has ever taken such care with the little things. It made all the difference."This is the essence of Conrad Dubai: not just meeting expectations, but exceeding them with intuitive, personalized service. Because luxury isnâ€™t just what we doâ€”itâ€™s how we make you feel. âœ¨ hashtag#LuxuryRedefined hashtag#AnticipatoryService hashtag#ConradMoments

Remember The Devil Wears Prada? Dubai is the 2.0 version. Welcome to modern slavery in designer clothes. Since being based here as a freelancer, I've had many people reach out with job offers and opportunities. While this city is known for its glitz and glamour, there are some hard lessons Iâ€™ve learned that I think are important for anyone considering a move here.- While Dubai offers perks like zero income tax and attractive salaries, there are some important realities to consider:-Job security can be shaky â€“ you can be terminated without any explanation during your probation period.-Your immigration status is tied to your employment, and unless you have a golden visa, your residency can be at risk if your job ends suddenly.-The cost of living is high, and even with a half a million salary in your country per month, it might not be enough to cover everything.-Accommodation is super expensive, and itâ€™s rarely paid monthly. In most cases, youâ€™ll be expected to pay rent in 1 or worse case 2 instalments â€“ or best, 4 months upfront â€“ plus all your utility bills on top (electricity, water, air con internet, tv etc.). Your employer will not necessarily pay for hotel costs pending you find an accommodation. -Work culture here can be intense â€“ if your boss works 24/7, so will you, as well as other dodgy work conditions that you cannot fight and under constant pressure of potential termination and deportation.-Forget employment rights. Forget human rights.The city might shine, but not everything that glitters is gold. Be informed, be cautious, and ask the right questions before saying yes.hashtag#Dubai hashtag#FreelancerLife hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#JobOpportunities hashtag#LivingInDubai hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#Immigration hashtag#GoldenVisa hashtag#RealityCheck hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#ExpatLife hashtag#CostOfLiving hashtag#RentalReality hashtag#Utilities hashtag#HardTruths hashtag#ModernSlavery

Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

Trump-Era Tariffs 2.0: Why Dubai Could Be the Biggest Winner!---------------------------------------------------------------------In 2024, the total bilateral trade between the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the United States reached $34.4 billion, marking a significant increase from previous years. This trade volume comprised $26.9 billion in U.S. exports to the UAE and $7.5 billion in imports from the UAE, resulting in a $19.5 billion trade surplus for the U.S.â€”its fourth-largest globally.With the potential return of Trump-era tariffs under a â€œTrump 2.0â€ administration, the UAEâ€”particularly Dubaiâ€”is poised to benefit significantly compared to much of the rest of the world, especially China. As global manufacturers and exporters seek alternative trade routes to bypass high tariffs, Dubai is emerging as a strategic export and re-export hub for Chinese-manufactured goods destined for the U.S. market.This shift positions Dubai not just as a logistics gateway, but as a key trading intermediary between China and the United States, unlocking a new phase of trade growth. In the coming months, this dynamic is expected to fuel unprecedented increases in exports from the UAE to the U.S., as well as reciprocal trade flows.The ripple effects of this transformation will be profoundâ€”particularly for Dubaiâ€™s real estate sector. The demand for commercial infrastructure, including warehouses, logistics parks, and office spaces, is expected to surge. Simultaneously, the residential market is likely to experience heightened demand, driven by business expansion, workforce inflow, and investor interest. Together, these trends are set to reinforce Dubaiâ€™s position as a global trading and real estate hotspot.

Free zones like Dubai Internet City and Jebel Ali are magnets for digital entrepreneurs. Women-led startups are also reshaping the industry, with innovative businesses across fashion, beauty, and digital services.Challenges for E-Commerce FoundersWhile the opportunities are abundant, challenges persist. Remember The Devil Wears Prada? Dubai is the 2.0 version. Welcome to modern slavery in designer clothes. Since being based here as a freelancer, I've had many people reach out with job offers and opportunities. While this city is known for its glitz and glamour, there are some hard lessons Iâ€™ve learned that I think are important for anyone considering a move here.- While Dubai offers perks like zero income tax and attractive salaries, there are some important realities to consider:-Job security can be shaky â€“ you can be terminated without any explanation during your probation period.-Your immigration status is tied to your employment, and unless you have a golden visa, your residency can be at risk if your job ends suddenly.-The cost of living is high, and even with a half a million salary in your country per month, it might not be enough to cover everything.-Accommodation is super expensive, and itâ€™s rarely paid monthly. In most cases, youâ€™ll be expected to pay rent in 1 or worse case 2 instalments â€“ or best, 4 months upfront â€“ plus all your utility bills on top (electricity, water, air con internet, tv etc.). Your employer will not necessarily pay for hotel costs pending you find an accommodation. -Work culture here can be intense â€“ if your boss works 24/7, so will you, as well as other dodgy work conditions that you cannot fight and under constant pressure of potential termination and deportation.-Forget employment rights. Forget human rights.The city might shine, but not everything that glitters is gold. Be informed, be cautious, and ask the right questions before saying yes.hashtag#Dubai hashtag#FreelancerLife hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#JobOpportunities hashtag#LivingInDubai hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#Immigration hashtag#GoldenVisa hashtag#RealityCheck hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#ExpatLife hashtag#CostOfLiving hashtag#RentalReality hashtag#Utilities hashtag#HardTruths hashtag#ModernSlavery

Username: Raad Mahmoud Al TalRaad Mahmoud Al Tal
Post Content:
The government is now clearly working within the framework of the Economic Modernization Vision, which is Jordanâ€™s roadmap for achieving sustainable growth by focusing on key parts of the economy. In 2024, macroeconomic indicators showed stability. The economy grew by 2.5 per cent and inflation stayed low at 2.21 per cent. GDP per person reached 3,228 dinars. The budget deficit after aid remained low at 0.7 per cent of GDP. Foreign currency reserves were $22 billion in March 2025, enough to cover 8.5 months of imports. Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

Trump-Era Tariffs 2.0: Why Dubai Could Be the Biggest Winner!---------------------------------------------------------------------In 2024, the total bilateral trade between the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the United States reached $34.4 billion, marking a significant increase from previous years. This trade volume comprised $26.9 billion in U.S. exports to the UAE and $7.5 billion in imports from the UAE, resulting in a $19.5 billion trade surplus for the U.S.â€”its fourth-largest globally.With the potential return of Trump-era tariffs under a â€œTrump 2.0â€ administration, the UAEâ€”particularly Dubaiâ€”is poised to benefit significantly compared to much of the rest of the world, especially China. As global manufacturers and exporters seek alternative trade routes to bypass high tariffs, Dubai is emerging as a strategic export and re-export hub for Chinese-manufactured goods destined for the U.S. market.This shift positions Dubai not just as a logistics gateway, but as a key trading intermediary between China and the United States, unlocking a new phase of trade growth. In the coming months, this dynamic is expected to fuel unprecedented increases in exports from the UAE to the U.S., as well as reciprocal trade flows.The ripple effects of this transformation will be profoundâ€”particularly for Dubaiâ€™s real estate sector. The demand for commercial infrastructure, including warehouses, logistics parks, and office spaces, is expected to surge. Simultaneously, the residential market is likely to experience heightened demand, driven by business expansion, workforce inflow, and investor interest. Together, these trends are set to reinforce Dubaiâ€™s position as a global trading and real estate hotspot.

Remember The Devil Wears Prada? Dubai is the 2.0 version. Welcome to modern slavery in designer clothes. Since being based here as a freelancer, I've had many people reach out with job offers and opportunities. While this city is known for its glitz and glamour, there are some hard lessons Iâ€™ve learned that I think are important for anyone considering a move here.- While Dubai offers perks like zero income tax and attractive salaries, there are some important realities to consider:-Job security can be shaky â€“ you can be terminated without any explanation during your probation period.-Your immigration status is tied to your employment, and unless you have a golden visa, your residency can be at risk if your job ends suddenly.-The cost of living is high, and even with a half a million salary in your country per month, it might not be enough to cover everything.-Accommodation is super expensive, and itâ€™s rarely paid monthly. In most cases, youâ€™ll be expected to pay rent in 1 or worse case 2 instalments â€“ or best, 4 months upfront â€“ plus all your utility bills on top (electricity, water, air con internet, tv etc.). Your employer will not necessarily pay for hotel costs pending you find an accommodation. -Work culture here can be intense â€“ if your boss works 24/7, so will you, as well as other dodgy work conditions that you cannot fight and under constant pressure of potential termination and deportation.-Forget employment rights. Forget human rights.The city might shine, but not everything that glitters is gold. Be informed, be cautious, and ask the right questions before saying yes.hashtag#Dubai hashtag#FreelancerLife hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#JobOpportunities hashtag#LivingInDubai hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#Immigration hashtag#GoldenVisa hashtag#RealityCheck hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#ExpatLife hashtag#CostOfLiving hashtag#RentalReality hashtag#Utilities hashtag#HardTruths hashtag#ModernSlavery

In 2024, macroeconomic indicators showed stability. The economy grew by 2.5 per cent and inflation stayed low at 2.21 per cent. GDP per person reached 3,228 dinars. Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

Safety in Dubai is truly unmatched, and itâ€™s one of the cityâ€™s most remarkable qualities. Even at 2 a.m.,,the streets are alive as if the evening has just begun..Families with young children, women walking alone or in groups, and friends hanging out without a single worry. Thereâ€™s a deep sense of security and peace that allows residents and tourists to enjoy life freely at any hour. The UAE job market in 2025 is showing strong growth, with around 69% of employers planning to hire, particularly in tech, healthcare, finance, and tourism. As the economy expands, roles in AI, cybersecurity, nursing, and regulatory finance are in high demand, with competitive salaries and opportunities for advancement. A shift toward skills-based hiring is reshaping recruitment, and nearly 73% of professionals are open to job changes, driven by a desire for better benefits and career growth. However, increased competition from a rising expat workforce is prompting companies to be more selective, making upskilling and strategic networking more important than ever.

Trump-Era Tariffs 2.0: Why Dubai Could Be the Biggest Winner!---------------------------------------------------------------------In 2024, the total bilateral trade between the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the United States reached $34.4 billion, marking a significant increase from previous years. This trade volume comprised $26.9 billion in U.S. exports to the UAE and $7.5 billion in imports from the UAE, resulting in a $19.5 billion trade surplus for the U.S.â€”its fourth-largest globally.With the potential return of Trump-era tariffs under a â€œTrump 2.0â€ administration, the UAEâ€”particularly Dubaiâ€”is poised to benefit significantly compared to much of the rest of the world, especially China. As global manufacturers and exporters seek alternative trade routes to bypass high tariffs, Dubai is emerging as a strategic export and re-export hub for Chinese-manufactured goods destined for the U.S. market.This shift positions Dubai not just as a logistics gateway, but as a key trading intermediary between China and the United States, unlocking a new phase of trade growth. In the coming months, this dynamic is expected to fuel unprecedented increases in exports from the UAE to the U.S., as well as reciprocal trade flows.The ripple effects of this transformation will be profoundâ€”particularly for Dubaiâ€™s real estate sector. The demand for commercial infrastructure, including warehouses, logistics parks, and office spaces, is expected to surge. Simultaneously, the residential market is likely to experience heightened demand, driven by business expansion, workforce inflow, and investor interest. Together, these trends are set to reinforce Dubaiâ€™s position as a global trading and real estate hotspot.

Remember The Devil Wears Prada? Dubai is the 2.0 version. Welcome to modern slavery in designer clothes. Since being based here as a freelancer, I've had many people reach out with job offers and opportunities. While this city is known for its glitz and glamour, there are some hard lessons Iâ€™ve learned that I think are important for anyone considering a move here.- While Dubai offers perks like zero income tax and attractive salaries, there are some important realities to consider:-Job security can be shaky â€“ you can be terminated without any explanation during your probation period.-Your immigration status is tied to your employment, and unless you have a golden visa, your residency can be at risk if your job ends suddenly.-The cost of living is high, and even with a half a million salary in your country per month, it might not be enough to cover everything.-Accommodation is super expensive, and itâ€™s rarely paid monthly. In most cases, youâ€™ll be expected to pay rent in 1 or worse case 2 instalments â€“ or best, 4 months upfront â€“ plus all your utility bills on top (electricity, water, air con internet, tv etc.). Your employer will not necessarily pay for hotel costs pending you find an accommodation. -Work culture here can be intense â€“ if your boss works 24/7, so will you, as well as other dodgy work conditions that you cannot fight and under constant pressure of potential termination and deportation.-Forget employment rights. Forget human rights.The city might shine, but not everything that glitters is gold. Be informed, be cautious, and ask the right questions before saying yes.hashtag#Dubai hashtag#FreelancerLife hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#JobOpportunities hashtag#LivingInDubai hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#Immigration hashtag#GoldenVisa hashtag#RealityCheck hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#ExpatLife hashtag#CostOfLiving hashtag#RentalReality hashtag#Utilities hashtag#HardTruths hashtag#ModernSlavery

The Dubai real estate market has experienced remarkable growth due to population growth and continued demand, as highlighted by the new industry report. According to ValuStrat, the population reached 3.92 million by March 2025, with 89,695 new residents added in  the first quarter. Demand for living space is rising, leading to an estimated 61,580 new homes expected  this year, with 19% already completed in the first quarter.Residential marketThe Valustrat Price Index (VPI) reports a significant annual increase in residential capital value. Apartments prices rose 21.4%, while villa prices rose 30.3%. Rental prices have also risen, with villa rentals rising 5.1% and housing rents rising 10%. Despite  demand, it is becoming increasingly difficult to secure affordable living spaces. The guilt of the whole of the total sin of the Dubai living sector reflects the non-attack between supply and demand, leading to  potential market corrections. In the first quarter of 2025,  sales transactions returned to residential buildings. This was due to fewer mortgage applications than previous quarters.Office marketThe office sector remains robust, with  annual  capital value increasing by 29.1% and research rents increasing by 20.2%. Demand for office space is supported by continuous economic growth and business expansion. The average office rating is AED per 20,591 square meters, which is the highest priced in Dubai city centre.

Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

Trump-Era Tariffs 2.0: Why Dubai Could Be the Biggest Winner!---------------------------------------------------------------------In 2024, the total bilateral trade between the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the United States reached $34.4 billion, marking a significant increase from previous years. This trade volume comprised $26.9 billion in U.S. exports to the UAE and $7.5 billion in imports from the UAE, resulting in a $19.5 billion trade surplus for the U.S.â€”its fourth-largest globally.With the potential return of Trump-era tariffs under a â€œTrump 2.0â€ administration, the UAEâ€”particularly Dubaiâ€”is poised to benefit significantly compared to much of the rest of the world, especially China. As global manufacturers and exporters seek alternative trade routes to bypass high tariffs, Dubai is emerging as a strategic export and re-export hub for Chinese-manufactured goods destined for the U.S. market.This shift positions Dubai not just as a logistics gateway, but as a key trading intermediary between China and the United States, unlocking a new phase of trade growth. In the coming months, this dynamic is expected to fuel unprecedented increases in exports from the UAE to the U.S., as well as reciprocal trade flows.The ripple effects of this transformation will be profoundâ€”particularly for Dubaiâ€™s real estate sector. The demand for commercial infrastructure, including warehouses, logistics parks, and office spaces, is expected to surge. Simultaneously, the residential market is likely to experience heightened demand, driven by business expansion, workforce inflow, and investor interest. Together, these trends are set to reinforce Dubaiâ€™s position as a global trading and real estate hotspot.

Remember The Devil Wears Prada? Dubai is the 2.0 version. Welcome to modern slavery in designer clothes. Since being based here as a freelancer, I've had many people reach out with job offers and opportunities. While this city is known for its glitz and glamour, there are some hard lessons Iâ€™ve learned that I think are important for anyone considering a move here.- While Dubai offers perks like zero income tax and attractive salaries, there are some important realities to consider:-Job security can be shaky â€“ you can be terminated without any explanation during your probation period.-Your immigration status is tied to your employment, and unless you have a golden visa, your residency can be at risk if your job ends suddenly.-The cost of living is high, and even with a half a million salary in your country per month, it might not be enough to cover everything.-Accommodation is super expensive, and itâ€™s rarely paid monthly. In most cases, youâ€™ll be expected to pay rent in 1 or worse case 2 instalments â€“ or best, 4 months upfront â€“ plus all your utility bills on top (electricity, water, air con internet, tv etc.). Your employer will not necessarily pay for hotel costs pending you find an accommodation. -Work culture here can be intense â€“ if your boss works 24/7, so will you, as well as other dodgy work conditions that you cannot fight and under constant pressure of potential termination and deportation.-Forget employment rights. Forget human rights.The city might shine, but not everything that glitters is gold. Be informed, be cautious, and ask the right questions before saying yes.hashtag#Dubai hashtag#FreelancerLife hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#JobOpportunities hashtag#LivingInDubai hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#Immigration hashtag#GoldenVisa hashtag#RealityCheck hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#ExpatLife hashtag#CostOfLiving hashtag#RentalReality hashtag#Utilities hashtag#HardTruths hashtag#ModernSlavery

The Dubai real estate market has experienced remarkable growth due to population growth and continued demand, as highlighted by the new industry report. According to ValuStrat, the population reached 3.92 million by March 2025, with 89,695 new residents added in  the first quarter. Demand for living space is rising, leading to an estimated 61,580 new homes expected  this year, with 19% already completed in the first quarter.Residential marketThe Valustrat Price Index (VPI) reports a significant annual increase in residential capital value. Apartments prices rose 21.4%, while villa prices rose 30.3%. Rental prices have also risen, with villa rentals rising 5.1% and housing rents rising 10%. Despite  demand, it is becoming increasingly difficult to secure affordable living spaces. The guilt of the whole of the total sin of the Dubai living sector reflects the non-attack between supply and demand, leading to  potential market corrections. In the first quarter of 2025,  sales transactions returned to residential buildings. This was due to fewer mortgage applications than previous quarters.Office marketThe office sector remains robust, with  annual  capital value increasing by 29.1% and research rents increasing by 20.2%. Demand for office space is supported by continuous economic growth and business expansion. The average office rating is AED per 20,591 square meters, which is the highest priced in Dubai city centre.

Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

Trump-Era Tariffs 2.0: Why Dubai Could Be the Biggest Winner!---------------------------------------------------------------------In 2024, the total bilateral trade between the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the United States reached $34.4 billion, marking a significant increase from previous years. This trade volume comprised $26.9 billion in U.S. exports to the UAE and $7.5 billion in imports from the UAE, resulting in a $19.5 billion trade surplus for the U.S.â€”its fourth-largest globally.With the potential return of Trump-era tariffs under a â€œTrump 2.0â€ administration, the UAEâ€”particularly Dubaiâ€”is poised to benefit significantly compared to much of the rest of the world, especially China. As global manufacturers and exporters seek alternative trade routes to bypass high tariffs, Dubai is emerging as a strategic export and re-export hub for Chinese-manufactured goods destined for the U.S. market.This shift positions Dubai not just as a logistics gateway, but as a key trading intermediary between China and the United States, unlocking a new phase of trade growth. In the coming months, this dynamic is expected to fuel unprecedented increases in exports from the UAE to the U.S., as well as reciprocal trade flows.The ripple effects of this transformation will be profoundâ€”particularly for Dubaiâ€™s real estate sector. The demand for commercial infrastructure, including warehouses, logistics parks, and office spaces, is expected to surge. Simultaneously, the residential market is likely to experience heightened demand, driven by business expansion, workforce inflow, and investor interest. Together, these trends are set to reinforce Dubaiâ€™s position as a global trading and real estate hotspot.

Remember The Devil Wears Prada? Dubai is the 2.0 version. Welcome to modern slavery in designer clothes. Since being based here as a freelancer, I've had many people reach out with job offers and opportunities. While this city is known for its glitz and glamour, there are some hard lessons Iâ€™ve learned that I think are important for anyone considering a move here.- While Dubai offers perks like zero income tax and attractive salaries, there are some important realities to consider:-Job security can be shaky â€“ you can be terminated without any explanation during your probation period.-Your immigration status is tied to your employment, and unless you have a golden visa, your residency can be at risk if your job ends suddenly.-The cost of living is high, and even with a half a million salary in your country per month, it might not be enough to cover everything.-Accommodation is super expensive, and itâ€™s rarely paid monthly. In most cases, youâ€™ll be expected to pay rent in 1 or worse case 2 instalments â€“ or best, 4 months upfront â€“ plus all your utility bills on top (electricity, water, air con internet, tv etc.). Your employer will not necessarily pay for hotel costs pending you find an accommodation. -Work culture here can be intense â€“ if your boss works 24/7, so will you, as well as other dodgy work conditions that you cannot fight and under constant pressure of potential termination and deportation.-Forget employment rights. Forget human rights.The city might shine, but not everything that glitters is gold. Be informed, be cautious, and ask the right questions before saying yes.hashtag#Dubai hashtag#FreelancerLife hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#JobOpportunities hashtag#LivingInDubai hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#Immigration hashtag#GoldenVisa hashtag#RealityCheck hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#ExpatLife hashtag#CostOfLiving hashtag#RentalReality hashtag#Utilities hashtag#HardTruths hashtag#ModernSlavery

The Dubai real estate market has experienced remarkable growth due to population growth and continued demand, as highlighted by the new industry report. According to ValuStrat, the population reached 3.92 million by March 2025, with 89,695 new residents added in  the first quarter. Demand for living space is rising, leading to an estimated 61,580 new homes expected  this year, with 19% already completed in the first quarter.Residential marketThe Valustrat Price Index (VPI) reports a significant annual increase in residential capital value. Apartments prices rose 21.4%, while villa prices rose 30.3%. Rental prices have also risen, with villa rentals rising 5.1% and housing rents rising 10%. Despite  demand, it is becoming increasingly difficult to secure affordable living spaces. The guilt of the whole of the total sin of the Dubai living sector reflects the non-attack between supply and demand, leading to  potential market corrections. In the first quarter of 2025,  sales transactions returned to residential buildings. This was due to fewer mortgage applications than previous quarters.Office marketThe office sector remains robust, with  annual  capital value increasing by 29.1% and research rents increasing by 20.2%. Demand for office space is supported by continuous economic growth and business expansion. The average office rating is AED per 20,591 square meters, which is the highest priced in Dubai city centre.

Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

Trump-Era Tariffs 2.0: Why Dubai Could Be the Biggest Winner!---------------------------------------------------------------------In 2024, the total bilateral trade between the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the United States reached $34.4 billion, marking a significant increase from previous years. This trade volume comprised $26.9 billion in U.S. exports to the UAE and $7.5 billion in imports from the UAE, resulting in a $19.5 billion trade surplus for the U.S.â€”its fourth-largest globally.With the potential return of Trump-era tariffs under a â€œTrump 2.0â€ administration, the UAEâ€”particularly Dubaiâ€”is poised to benefit significantly compared to much of the rest of the world, especially China. As global manufacturers and exporters seek alternative trade routes to bypass high tariffs, Dubai is emerging as a strategic export and re-export hub for Chinese-manufactured goods destined for the U.S. market.This shift positions Dubai not just as a logistics gateway, but as a key trading intermediary between China and the United States, unlocking a new phase of trade growth. In the coming months, this dynamic is expected to fuel unprecedented increases in exports from the UAE to the U.S., as well as reciprocal trade flows.The ripple effects of this transformation will be profoundâ€”particularly for Dubaiâ€™s real estate sector. The demand for commercial infrastructure, including warehouses, logistics parks, and office spaces, is expected to surge. Simultaneously, the residential market is likely to experience heightened demand, driven by business expansion, workforce inflow, and investor interest. Together, these trends are set to reinforce Dubaiâ€™s position as a global trading and real estate hotspot.

Inside the E-Commerce Boom in the UAE: Opportunities, Challenges, and the Road AheadBy Nigar ValiyevaThe UAEâ€™s e-commerce sector is boomingâ€”and Iâ€™ve lived it from the inside.From founding multiple startups in Dubai to navigating growth and competition, Iâ€™ve seen firsthand what makes this market so powerfulâ€”and where the real challenges lie.In this article, I share key insights, lessons for entrepreneurs, and what the road ahead looks like for digital commerce in the region.Read, comment, and share if you believe in the power of entrepreneurship.hashtag#UAE hashtag#Ecommerce hashtag#Startups hashtag#DigitalBusiness hashtag#WomenInBusiness hashtag#Entrepreneurship hashtag#DubaiThe UAE has quickly become a leading e-commerce hub in the Middle East, thanks to technological advancements, government initiatives, and a tech-savvy population. With platforms like Noon and Amazon becoming household names, the market has seen exponential growth, especially in sectors like fashion, electronics, and food delivery.Opportunities for EntrepreneursThe UAE offers an ideal environment for e-commerce startups, with attractive tax policies and a business-friendly infrastructure. Free zones like Dubai Internet City and Jebel Ali are magnets for digital entrepreneurs. Women-led startups are also reshaping the industry, with innovative businesses across fashion, beauty, and digital services.Challenges for E-Commerce FoundersWhile the opportunities are abundant, challenges persist. Global players like Amazon and Noon dominate, making it tough for smaller players. Additionally, high digital marketing costs, brand visibility issues, and cultural expectations are barriers to success. Businesses must focus on trust, quality, and innovation to stay competitive.Key Takeaways â€¢	Customer Experience is King: Simplified, fast service builds loyalty. â€¢	Niche Wins: Unique positioning helps small brands stand out. â€¢	Consistency & Adaptability: Be ready to pivot based on data and trends.Looking AheadThe future of UAEâ€™s e-commerce will be shaped by technologyâ€”AI, AR, cross-border selling, and fintech integration. Remember The Devil Wears Prada? Dubai is the 2.0 version. Welcome to modern slavery in designer clothes. Since being based here as a freelancer, I've had many people reach out with job offers and opportunities. While this city is known for its glitz and glamour, there are some hard lessons Iâ€™ve learned that I think are important for anyone considering a move here.- While Dubai offers perks like zero income tax and attractive salaries, there are some important realities to consider:-Job security can be shaky â€“ you can be terminated without any explanation during your probation period.-Your immigration status is tied to your employment, and unless you have a golden visa, your residency can be at risk if your job ends suddenly.-The cost of living is high, and even with a half a million salary in your country per month, it might not be enough to cover everything.-Accommodation is super expensive, and itâ€™s rarely paid monthly. In most cases, youâ€™ll be expected to pay rent in 1 or worse case 2 instalments â€“ or best, 4 months upfront â€“ plus all your utility bills on top (electricity, water, air con internet, tv etc.). Your employer will not necessarily pay for hotel costs pending you find an accommodation. -Work culture here can be intense â€“ if your boss works 24/7, so will you, as well as other dodgy work conditions that you cannot fight and under constant pressure of potential termination and deportation.-Forget employment rights. Forget human rights.The city might shine, but not everything that glitters is gold. Be informed, be cautious, and ask the right questions before saying yes.hashtag#Dubai hashtag#FreelancerLife hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#JobOpportunities hashtag#LivingInDubai hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#Immigration hashtag#GoldenVisa hashtag#RealityCheck hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#ExpatLife hashtag#CostOfLiving hashtag#RentalReality hashtag#Utilities hashtag#HardTruths hashtag#ModernSlavery

The Dubai real estate market has experienced remarkable growth due to population growth and continued demand, as highlighted by the new industry report. According to ValuStrat, the population reached 3.92 million by March 2025, with 89,695 new residents added in  the first quarter. Demand for living space is rising, leading to an estimated 61,580 new homes expected  this year, with 19% already completed in the first quarter.Residential marketThe Valustrat Price Index (VPI) reports a significant annual increase in residential capital value. Apartments prices rose 21.4%, while villa prices rose 30.3%. Rental prices have also risen, with villa rentals rising 5.1% and housing rents rising 10%. Despite  demand, it is becoming increasingly difficult to secure affordable living spaces. The guilt of the whole of the total sin of the Dubai living sector reflects the non-attack between supply and demand, leading to  potential market corrections. In the first quarter of 2025,  sales transactions returned to residential buildings. This was due to fewer mortgage applications than previous quarters.Office marketThe office sector remains robust, with  annual  capital value increasing by 29.1% and research rents increasing by 20.2%. Demand for office space is supported by continuous economic growth and business expansion. The average office rating is AED per 20,591 square meters, which is the highest priced in Dubai city centre.

Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

Trump-Era Tariffs 2.0: Why Dubai Could Be the Biggest Winner!---------------------------------------------------------------------In 2024, the total bilateral trade between the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the United States reached $34.4 billion, marking a significant increase from previous years. This trade volume comprised $26.9 billion in U.S. exports to the UAE and $7.5 billion in imports from the UAE, resulting in a $19.5 billion trade surplus for the U.S.â€”its fourth-largest globally.With the potential return of Trump-era tariffs under a â€œTrump 2.0â€ administration, the UAEâ€”particularly Dubaiâ€”is poised to benefit significantly compared to much of the rest of the world, especially China. As global manufacturers and exporters seek alternative trade routes to bypass high tariffs, Dubai is emerging as a strategic export and re-export hub for Chinese-manufactured goods destined for the U.S. market.This shift positions Dubai not just as a logistics gateway, but as a key trading intermediary between China and the United States, unlocking a new phase of trade growth. In the coming months, this dynamic is expected to fuel unprecedented increases in exports from the UAE to the U.S., as well as reciprocal trade flows.The ripple effects of this transformation will be profoundâ€”particularly for Dubaiâ€™s real estate sector. The demand for commercial infrastructure, including warehouses, logistics parks, and office spaces, is expected to surge. Simultaneously, the residential market is likely to experience heightened demand, driven by business expansion, workforce inflow, and investor interest. Together, these trends are set to reinforce Dubaiâ€™s position as a global trading and real estate hotspot.
